Being a Speed Champions and Formula 1 fan this was a bit of a must-buy. After eventually buying and building the set it took me a few days to make up my mind about it...
Building
There are a lot of different elements to build for this set, some more interesting than others.
There are two track sections, suggesting a street circuit like Monaco. They are very simple and only take minutes to put together. There'
column2: s also a section of pit wall. Using some clever combinations of clips and bars this is a more interesting section to build.

column1: Next up there'
column2: s a podium for the race winners. There&#39
column3: s a clever mechanism to rotate parts of the podium structure so you can switch between race coverage and podium celebration. The last big element that&#39
column4: s not a car is a pit box. A very simple structure to put together but with a few nice details.

column1: Finally of course there are the two race cars. Apart from the number and the colour of the camera on top they are identical and the construction is similar to the other F1 cars in the theme sofar. They are not difficult to build and use a little SNOT to good effect for the shape of a modern F1 car. There must be a rule in the set-designers handbook that explains why these F1 cars all use 1x1 Technic bricks with a half pin instead of using a 1x1 brick with a stud on the side. I don'

column1: Then there are some smaller items like a fuel/diagnostics trolley, a camera and.... a hotdog stand.
Parts
This set is just shy of 1000 parts and they'

column1: Some white bricks, plates and slopes for the track sections, some Technic parts for some moving parts, and lots of black and grey plates, clips, tiles and other parts. Among the more interesting parts are 7 classic garden fences in black, some pizza-slice tiles in green and a hot dog bun. To balance all the tiny parts there are also some large supports, panels and plates to give the structures some volume.

column1: Conclusion

Like some other Speed Champions sets this one is trying to be two things. In this case the realistic depiction of the Mercedes AMG F1 team takes a backseat with play features taking centre stage. As a play set you couldn'
column5: s enough there to play out many scenarios around an F1 race.

column1: The repetition of two identical cars is inevitable when you do an F1 team but is not a problem. I would have liked to see Lewis Hamilton and Valtteri Bottas minifigs
column2: (and number 77 on the second car) but that would have been out of step with the rest of the Speed Champions theme.

column1: This is not a cheap set but it offers good value for money. You get 100 more parts than in 75889 Ferrari Garage that sells at the same price. Despite having one less car than the Ferrari set this one feels more substantial.
It may not be the most challenging set to build and it may not be the most accurate model of an F1 pit box but I can recommend this set to both adult F1 fans and children.
